awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ABI Innovation: Plant Genotype-Phenotype (G2P) Association Discovery via Integrative Genome-scale Biological Network & Genome-wide Association Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the mechanisms of genotype and phenotype (G2P) associations has been an important and challenging task in modern biology. The challenge lies in the high-dimensional gene variables and the complexity of gene regulation and interactions that collectively define particular phenotypes (also called traits). The project will develop innovative methods, tools and bioinformatics systems to decipher the plant G2P associations through integrative genome-scale biological network and genome-wide association analysis. A breakthrough in this work will lead to a systems-level understanding of how biological processes, pathways and complex traits in plants are hierarchically regulated. Advancing such fundamental knowledge will greatly benefit modern genome-assisted plant breeding by providing the underlying regulatory mechanisms and key regulators of agriculturally important traits. This in turn will have great potential to be translated into new means of improving plant quality and production for agriculture, thus benefiting society as a whole. Cutting-edge technologies will be developed to study G2P associations in plants, providing excellent opportunities for training undergraduates, graduates and postdocs in interdisciplinary fields such as computational biology, bioinformatics, plant genomics, and statistical genetics, at the three institutes. Underrepresented minorities and women will be especially targeted in the recruitment of the project. The research will form the basis of the proposed educational workshops centering on bioinformatics and statistical genetics. Creative and innovative hands-on outreach activities will be arranged through the three institutes? outreach programs with local K-12 schools to inspire young minds to become bioinformatics scientists. 

Innovative methods will be developed to analyze genome-scale biological networks and genome-wide associations through a fully integrated bioinformatics platform, enabling the discovery of G2P associations in plants. Specific aims of the project include 1) to develop novel top-down and bottom-up graphical Gaussian model (GGM) algorithms to reconstruct the hierarchical gene networks that control biological processes and pathways; 2) to develop models and algorithms that enable large-scale marker-trait association analysis with high precision using novel statistical genetics approaches; and 3) to develop a Graph-search-empowered integrative bioinformatics platform to facilitate the integration, deciphering and discovery of G2P associations. To validate our approaches and tools, public data from genome-wide plant 'omics' studies and genome-wide association studies (GWAS) will be integrated and analyzed, associating traits with SNP markers and fine-tuning the prediction of phenotype-associated hierarchical and/or pleiotropic regulators and functional networks. The novel knowledge and analytic methods and tools yielded from this project will be disseminated into the public at large through presentations, publications and web applications. All the tools and data resources will be made freely available at http://plantgrn.org/ to the plant research communities, accelerating plant bioinformatics and plant science research, education and applications.

I. SUMMARY 

This award is part of three collaborative research awards (Award #1458597 to the principal investigator (PI) Dr. Patrick Xuechun Zhao at the Noble Research Institute [NRI]; Award #1458130 to PI Dr. Hairong Wei at the Michigan Technological University [MTU]; and Award #1458515 to PI Dr. Shizhong Xu at the University of California, Riverside [UCR]) entitled: Collaborative Research: ABI Innovation: Plant Genotype-Phenotype (G2P) Association Discovery via Integrative Genome-scale Biological Network & Genome-wide Association Analysis.

Our collaborative research has enabled the participants to develop innovative bioinformatics methods, tools, and technologies to study phenotype-genotypes associations. We successfully achieved all the specific objectives. The publications, bioinformatics web servers, and biological databases have been disseminated timely. These deliverables have been used to discover novel genes, decipher G2P associations, and understand the complexity of gene regulation and interactions. The generated knowledge, data resources, and tools already benefit the modern genome-assisted plant breeding by providing the underlying mechanisms and key regulators of agriculturally important traits. These, in turn, are translating into new means of improving plant quality and production for agriculture. 

This project provided excellent opportunities to train postdoctoral researchers, undergraduate and graduate students, and intern scholars in transdisciplinary fields at three institutes: NRI, MTU, and UCR.

II. RESEARCH ACTIVITIES AND ACHIEVEMENTS

We adopted the "White-box" and "Black-box" approaches (Figure 1) as our research strategy for G2P association discovery. Our efforts thus centered on genome-scale biological networks and genome-wide associations (Figure 2), which enabled us to achieve all the planned specific objectives,

  • Development of novel top-down and bottom-up graphical Gaussian model algorithms to reconstruct the hierarchical gene networks that control biological processes and pathways.
  • Development of models and algorithms that enable large-scale single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) marker-trait association analysis with high precision using novel statistical genetics approaches.
  • Development of integrative bioinformatics platforms to facilitate the integration, deciphering, and discovery of G2P associations.

Publications

The PI's team efforts have resulted in twenty-three original peer-reviewed papers published in reputable scientific journals (Figure 3 and 4 show the list of publications).

Published Bioinformatics Tools, Web Servers, and Databases

We also successfully developed a series of web servers and databases to facilitate modeling and deciphering of plant transcriptional regulatory networks, which not only fulfill the needs of plant research and plant breeding but will also develop better molecular tools, ultimately leading to the development of better engineered economically important crops. Figure 5 lists the bioinformatics web server and databases developed through this project. These developments have been well received by the plant research communities, evident by their high usages and citations.

III. BROADER IMPACTS

We developed cutting-edge technologies to study G2P associations in plants, providing excellent opportunities for training undergraduates, graduates, and postdocs in interdisciplinary fields at the three institutes. We targeted underrepresented minorities and women during the recruitment of the project. The research formed the basis of proposed educational workshops. Hands-on outreach activities have been arranged through the three institutes, facilitating outreach programs with local K-12 schools to inspire young minds to become bioinformatics scientists.

Training Bioinformatics Postdoctoral Fellows and Research Associates

This proposal's work is trans-disciplinary, requiring the application of genomics, computational biology, and bioinformatics to classical genetics, molecular and cell biology, and plant physiology. The project has empowered postdoctoral fellows, students, and technical staff to learn many of the research skills essential for cutting-edge bioinformatics and biological research. Five postdoctoral research fellows and research associates have been trained.

Training Intern Students

The Noble Foundation has strong student education and outreach programs that have been harnessed to maximize teaching and learning outcomes in this project. Through this project, the PI's Lab hosted two intern students from the University of Missouri in Columbia, MO, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 2017. Both intern students have pursued higher education lately.

Computer Demos and Bioinformatics Workshops

We annually presented talks, posters, and computer demos to introduce projects and give tutorials and hands-on training on our developed bioinformatics tools and databases to plant research communities, with about 50-70 participants each, at the Plant Animal Genome conferences in San Diego, CA.

We hosted two multi-day NSF Project / Bioinformatics Workshops. One at the Noble Research Institute, Ardmore OK, April 28 - 30, 2016, and another at the University of California, Riverside CA, April 14 - 15, 2018. We considered both workshops were incredibly successful because (a) they were very well received. For example, over 60 researchers attended the 2016 workshop (Figure 6, A group of workshop participants posing for a photo during break); and (b) New collaborative research was further developed following the workshops, resulting in several significant co-authored publications and collaborative research projects.

IV. CONCLUDING REMARK

The three labs worked seamlessly as a collaborative research team. Together, we have successfully fulfilled all specific aims, including the scientific R&D, planned education and outreach programs within the funding period.
